metadata.title: Headache, Migraine
anatomical location body part affected: Head, including brain and intracranial blood vessels, visual system; gastrointestinal system
description: Migraine headaches are severe, recurrent, long-lasting  headaches that may occur with or without an aura (i.e., visual or sensory disturbances typically occurring 1 hour prior to the onset of the headache) or prodromal symptoms (i.e., generalized symptoms that may occur days before headache)(2)
Migraine headaches with aura occur in 20% of persons with migraine headaches(2)
There can be substantial disability associated with migraine(12) ICD-10  codes
reimbursement: No specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified
presentation signs and symptoms: Usually characterized by moderate to severe unilateral head pain that then generalizes; majority of migraine patients have attacks on both sides, often described as pounding, throbbing pain.(1) Headache may also be described as a pressure headache (patient feels as if “head is in a vice”)
Symptoms may be accompanied by various focal disturbances of the nervous system, including sensitivity to light, noise, and odors, nausea/vomiting, and upset stomach or abdominal pain(1)
Symptoms generally last 4–72  hours(1) Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors

causes: The precise causes of migraine headaches are not known, but theories propose that theyare caused by brainstem changes affecting the trigeminal nerve. Other theories supportan inflammatory disease with a genetic basis that results in disturbances in serotonin useand activity(18)
pathogenesis: Migraine headaches are no longer considered vascular-based  phenomena (i.e., arterial constriction and dilatation). Differenttheories as to the cause/pathogenesis of migraine headaches have been proposed in the literature, such as activation andsensitization of the trigeminovascular pathways. Additionally, brain stem and diencephalic nuclei dysfunction may play arole in migraine symptoms such as light and sound sensitivity. A dysregulation of sensory processing, and/or a brain stateof altered excitability, is thought to be involved(1)
risk factors: Overuse of analgesics is associated with increased risk of chronic migraine(3)
Sex – women are 3 times more likely to have migraines than men
Medical conditions associated with migraines–Epilepsy, stroke, hypertension, and depression, anxiety, and other mood disorders have been associated with migraine
Obesity is a risk factor for migraine and for attack frequency(13)

overall contraindications precautions: Patients with migraine headaches must be examined by a physician prior to receiving physical therapy services
Refer to emergency services immediately if a neurological event (e.g., stroke) is suspected

Sudden-onset  headache or headache triggered by cough, exertion, or Valsalva maneuver is a red flag that could indicate subarachnoid hemorrhage or arteriovenous malformation (A VM) bleed. Refer to emergency services as indicated
See specific  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/Plan of Care

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Mechanism of injury or etiology of illness -When did patient first experience this type of headache? -How long is the asymptomatic period between migraine headaches (maximum, minimum, average)? -What is the frequency of migraines? -Does an aura precede the migraine? -When was diagnosis of migraines made? -Diagnosis of migraine is possible only after 5 recurrent episodes of severe or very severe unilateral orbital, supraorbital, and/or temporal pain lasting 15 to 180 minutes(5)

course of treatment.medical management: Medical management Migraine headaches typically are treated with medications Nonpharmacologic treatments that may be effective in some patients include cold (application of frozen gel pack to head) hyperbaric oxygen therapy dietary or lifestyle changes behavioral therapy biofeedback(4) counseling stress management(4) relaxation therapy(4)
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications clinician has prescribed; are they being taken? Are they effective? Medications should be administered immediately at symptom onset(4) Abortive medications used for treatment of migraine headache (during an attack) Agents include triptans,(4) dihydroergotamine, prochlorperazine, metoclopramide, acetaminophen (1,000 mg), ibuprofen, dexamethasone (as adjunctive therapy to reduce recurrence within 72 hours), and naproxen  Other agents that may be effective include ergotamine, diclofenac, a combination of sumatriptan and naproxen, dipyrone, aspirin (1,000 mg), lysine clonixinate, and topical menthol 10% solution Daily use of analgesics may increase migraine headache frequency and intensity Prophylactic medications generally are given if a patient has 2 or more migraine headaches a month; medications that may be prescribed include(11) antiepileptics (e.g., valproate and topiramate) antidepressants (e.g., amitriptyline) blood-pressure-lowering  medications (e.g., propranolol, metoprolol) botulinum toxin A injections calcitonin gene-related  peptide monoclonal antibodies (e.g., erenumab-aooe, fremanezumab-vfrm, galcanezumabgnlm)
diagnostic tests completed: The following tests may be ordered to rule out other medical conditions(13)
Lumbar puncture for history of abrupt onset of headaches and uncertain diagnosis

Imaging studies with presence of headache red flags such as unexplained abnormal findings on neurological examination, rapidly increasing frequency of headaches, history of dizziness or incoordination, headache causing waking from sleep, or headache worsening with Valsalva maneuver
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether they help Complementary and alternative medicine (CAM) interventions may include homeopathy, behavioral therapy, nutraceuticals, acupuncture, spinal manipulation, hypnosis, and electrical stimulation
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Does the patient report any headache triggers (e.g., certain lighting and foods may trigger migraines in some patients)? Please also see Risk factors , above. Is there anything that relieves patient’s pain? -Does the patient keep a headache log/diary? -Recording triggers of headaches, efficacy of treatments, and frequency/history of symptoms often is recommended
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: How long do symptoms last (maximum, minimum, average)? What associated symptoms are present? See Presentation/signs and symptoms , above
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Pattern of symptoms -When do migraine headaches occur? -How do migraine headaches begin? -What is the frequency of migraine headaches? -Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (A.M., mid-day,  P.M., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables -Refer to patient’s headache diary if available
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings/night, if any. Does the patient ever wake with a migraine headache?
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (e.g., aphasia, unilateral weakness, or any other symptoms that raise suspicion of a stroke or other neurological problem) Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe _______________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Previous history of same/similar diagnosis Many patients report a history of motion sickness and/or vertigo Individuals with migraine headaches, especially those who have migraine headaches with aura, often have a positive family history for migraine(1)
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Is there a history of vascular disease? Is there a history of head or cervical trauma? Does the patient have any known allergies? Inquire about any other comorbidities
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Medications previously prescribed Estrogen withdrawal, reductions in estrogen dose, and low-dose  estrogen supplementation have been associated with induction of migraine attacks(6)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he/she may be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: What is the patient’s occupation? Are there any environmental triggers at the patient’s workplace? Do the migraines interfere with patient’s ability to perform job duties or schoolwork?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Document any noted limitations or use of assistive/ adaptive devices
social and occupational history.living environment: Stairs, number of floors in home, with whom patient lives, caregivers, etc.

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting.)  Tests listed below are specific to migraine headaches; implement standard evaluation techniques as indicated •Anthropomorphic characteristics:  Measure height and weight and calculate BMI •Body mechanics/ergonomics: Assess as indicated
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Complete a general gait assessmentAssess passive mobility of cervical and thoracic spine; the clinician should also assess the temporomandibular joint
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Manual muscle testing (MMT) of the scapular, cervical, and shoulder muscles
relevant tests and measures.posture: Postural assessment for correct alignment of head, neck, thorax, ribs, and shoulders
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Assess cervical, shoulder, and thoracic ROM
relevant tests and measures.reflex testing: Assess upper and lower extremity reflexes and compare bilaterally
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests specific to diagnosis –Headache Screen(7) -The Headache Screen is composed of 3 simple questions -Do you have recurrent headaches that interfere with work, family, or social function? -Do your headaches last at least 4 hours untreated? -Have you had new or different headaches in the past 6 months? -Migraine headaches are diagnosed by a positive response to questions 1 and 2 and a negative response to question 3

contraindications precautions: Over areas with a lack of intact thermal sensation
Over areas of vascular insufficiency or vascular disease
Over areas of recent hemorrhage or potential hemorrhage
Over areas of known malignancy
Over areas of acute inflammation
Over infected areas where infection may spread
Over areas where liniments or heat rubs have recently been applied
In any situation deemed unreliable by the practitioner
Over the trunk or heart region in patients with demand-type pacemakers and implantable cardioverter defibrillators (ICDs)
Over the pelvic, abdominal, lumbar, or hip region of a pregnant woman
Over the carotid bodies
Over the phrenic nerve, eyes, or gonads
Over areas of known peripheral vascular disease
Over areas of active osteomyelitis
Over areas of hemorrhage
With patients without intact sensation
With patients who cannot communicate
With patients with compromised mental ability
With cardiac dysfunction (uncontrolled hypertension or hypotension, irregular heartbeat)
Over active or previous neoplasms
Over compromised skin
Over tissues that are vulnerable to hemorrhage
Cervical region in patients with history of stroke or seizures
Do not use within 5 yards of diathermy units or other source of electromagnetic radiation
other: Only those contraindications/precautions applicable to this diagnosis are mentioned below, including with regard to modalities. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment

Patients with this diagnosis may be at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention  strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention strategies

Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary presented below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Diagnosis/need for treatment Migraine headaches interfere with an individual’s function and ADLs Exercise may be effective for symptom management in patients with migraine headaches(4)
assessment plan of care.rule out: Rule out  (2) Tension headache Cluster headache Sinus infection Meningitis Subarachnoid hemorrhage (worst headache ever) Collagen vascular disorders CNS lesion Post-traumatic  headache Transient ischemic attack (TIA)
prognosis: A study in Spain followed a cohort of 380 migraine patients (77.1% women, mean age 41 years) for 10 years. Factors associated with migraine improvement were baseline frequency > 10 days per month, nonsmoking, and a medical follow-up  for migraine. Over the duration of the study, over half of the participants had improvements(17)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral to other disciplines Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) or biofeedback may be effective Massage therapy to release tension and trigger points Neurologist if the patient has neurological symptoms Physician for pharmacological intervention Referral for behavioral weight management services as indicated
other considerations: Acupuncture significantly reduced the frequency of migraine attacks compared to sham treatment in individuals with a history of migraine without aura(9) –Based on a randomized trial conducted in China –Two-hundred  forty-nine  individuals (77.1% women) participated in the study –Participants were randomly assigned into one of three groups: true acupuncture, sham acupuncture, and a waiting list group (who received acupuncture after the trial was completed) –Participants in the true acupuncture and sham acupuncture groups received treatment 5 days a week for 4 weeks
treatment summary: Studies have suggested that aerobic exercise may be beneficial for reducing migraine headache, and it is routinely recommended as a means of managing and preventing migraine, based on recommendations from health organizations such as the American Academy of Neurology, the American College of Physicians, and the American Headache Society(14) –However, the evidence is not definitive and several questions remain unanswered, including which individuals will benefit, whether there is a dose-response  curve, and what the optimal types and intensities of aerobic exercise are –It is also unclear whether aerobic exercise is an effective primary treatment and what mechanisms underlie its efficacy for migraine treatment

Suggestive evidence of the benefits of aerobic exercise includes the following studies: –Aerobic exercise may decrease pain intensity, frequency, and duration of migraines and increase quality of life (low-  to moderate-quality  evidence)(10) -Based on a 2020 systematic review and meta-analysis -Data from 10 studies and 508 individuals were included –Aerobic exercise may decrease the number of migraine days (moderate evidence), attack duration, and pain intensity (low-quality  evidence)(11) -Based on a 2019 systematic review and meta-analysis -A totalof six studies and 357 patients with migraine were included in the data. Mean patient age was 38 years and 88% of participants were women

Researchers in Brazil reported that a physical therapy protocol comprised mainly of manual therapy and stretching maneuvers did not promote additional improvement in migraine treatment beyond that provided by medication, but did enhance patient satisfaction(15) –Based on an RCT that involved 50 women with migraines who were randomized into a control group that received medication only or a group that received physical therapy plus medication –Patients in the physical therapy group received eight 50-minute  sessions of physical therapy over 4 weeks –Outcome measures included headache frequency, intensity, self-perception  of global change, pressure pain threshold, and cervical ROM –Both groups had a significant reduction in frequency of headaches, with no differences observed between the groups. The physical therapy group showed a decrease in pain intensity post treatment, but at follow-up  there was no difference in pain intensity between groups –Satisfaction with treatment was higher in the physiotherapy group –An increase in pressure pain threshold was observed in the physical therapy group that was not seen in the control group, but this difference was not reflected in the headache frequency or intensity. The authors suggest that this may indicate that functional improvement may precede clinical improvement or that the duration of the intervention should be longer

Researchers from Israel report that nonpainful remote skin stimulation can significantly reduce migraine pain, especially when applied early in an attack(16) –Based on a double-blinded,  randomized, crossover, sham-controlled  trial that involved 86 patients with episodic migraines with or without aura –A stimulating device consisting of electrodes mounted in an armband was controlled by the patient’s smartphone –Participants were instructed to mount the devices on their arms and activate them for 20 minutes as soon as possible after onset of an attack –Outcome measures included a numeric pain scale, which was used to calculate relative pain reduction. Percentage of patients reporting pain reduction was also calculated –Results showed a clear advantage of the stimulation protocol over the sham protocol –Early stimulation was nearly twice as effective as later stimulation  . Problem Goal Intervention Expected Progression Home Program Increased pain that limits functionDecrease pain Electrotherapeutic modalities _ Biofeedback; relaxation techniques to retrain muscle function and decrease muscle tension _ _ Aerobic exercise _ _ (See Treatment summary , above)Progress aerobic exercise as indicated for each patientRecommend and implement a home program centered on relaxation strategies and aerobic exercise as indicated Sensitivity to light, sound, and smells that limits the patient’s ability to complete ADLs and work-related tasksImprove the patient’s ability to complete functional activities during episodesElectrotherapeutic modalities _ Biofeedback; relaxation techniques to retrain muscle function and decrease muscle tension _ _ (See Treatment summary , above) _ _

decreased pain intensity: V AS, 1–10  scale, reported use of medication
improved patient ability to complete fun: Outcomes can be measured by patient self-assessment  questionnaires on functional ability during episodic periods–Neck Disability Index (NDI)–Headache Screen(7)

maintenance or prevention: Self-management  of compensatory symptoms with stretch and relaxation techniques
Behavior modification to limit exposure to triggers
Given the association between obesity and migraine headache,(13) clinicians should consider facilitating appropriate lifestyle changes for optimal headache management
Use of medication as needed and directed by physician
